content.rendered:
શ્રીમતિ કિરણ બેદી,

સમાજ માં કેવા વ્યવહાર ને આદર્શ ગણવું? આ પરિભાષા ને જેને સાકરિત કરી, અને બાળપણથી જ જેઓ મારા આદર્શ રહ્યા છે, એવા શ્રીમતિ કિરણ બેદી આપને સંબોધવા હું આજે પ્રેરાઈ છું.

કદાચ એ સાહસ, એ જુસ્સો મારામાં ન પણ હોઈ કે હું આપ જેવું મહાન કાર્ય કરી શકું, પણ હા તમારા જીવનને અનુલક્ષીને હું મારા જીવનને સારું એવું પ્રભાવશાળી તો બનાવી જ શકું. તેથી જ આપના વિષે લખાયું છે કે, “કિરણ બેદી પાસે મોહનદાસ ગાંધીની શિસ્ત, શક્તિ, નિશ્ચય, સંકલ્પ અને સ્થિતિસ્થાપકતા છે.” તો આ મને તદ્દન સાચું પ્રતીત થાય છે. તમારા જીવનપર્યંતના સંઘર્ષો અને સાહસ મને હંમેશા પ્રભાવિત કરતા રહ્યા છે. એક જુનિયર ટેનિસ ખેલાડીથી લઈ એક ભારતીય પોલીસ સેવામાં જોડાવા સુધીનો આપનો માર્ગ ખૂબ જ સાહસિક અને ધીરજ ભર્યો હતો એમ મને અનુભવ થયો. અને આ સમય દરમિયાનના તમારા સમાજ પ્રત્યેના કાર્યો અને સંઘર્ષ ને પણ સિદ્ધિ સુધી લઈ જનાર તરીકે તમારું નામ પહેલું આવે. અને તેથી જ આવા હકારાત્મક વલણ ને લીધે તમારી છબી પ્રસંશા પાત્ર છે.

આઝાદી પછીનો પણ અમુક સમય એવો હતો, જ્યારે લોકોના મનમાં સ્ત્રી-પુરુષ અંગે થોડા ભેદભાવ તો હતા જ. પુરુષોના ઉચ્ચ પદે ચાલતા સમયમાં એક સ્ત્રી તરીકે આપનું ભારતીય પોલીસ સેવા માં જોડાવવું , અને એ પણ ભારતની પ્રથમ મહિલા ઑફિસર બનવું , ખરેખર આપ માટે એક ખૂબ મોટા સાહસ અને મારા માટે ગૌરવની વાત કહેવાય. .આપના વટ અને પરિસ્થિતિ અનુસાર કઠણ સ્વભાવનું શું કહેવું! સાંભળ્યું છે કે, ભારતીય પોલીસ સેવામાં જોડાવા પહેલાની તાલીમમાં 80 માણસોના બેચમાં આપ એક માત્ર મહિલા હતી. દુષ્ટકર્મીઓ, ગુનેગારો વગેરેને આપણા નામથી જ એક બીક લાગતી , એક પોલીસ તરીકેનો આ વટ તમારા ‘લેડી સિંઘમ’ બિરુદને સમર્થન આપે છે. એક સ્ત્રી તરીકે આપનું આ વર્ચસ્વ મને ઘણું જ ઉત્સાહદાયી લાગ્યું. લોકો પ્રસંશા માત્ર ઊંચું પદ જોઈને જ કરે છે? ના.! એ માટે લોકો પ્રત્યે પ્રેમ, કાળજી , કરુણા પણ રાખવી જરૂરી છે. ‘ખુલ્લું બારણું’ નામક આપની લોકો સાથેના વાર્તાલાપની યોજના મને એ જ પ્રેમનું પ્રતીક લાગ્યું. ઉચ્ચ પદ તો માણસ મહેનત કરી મેળવી શકે છે. પરંતુ લોકોના મનમાં ઉચ્ચપદ મેળવવા માટે એમના પ્રત્યે પ્રેમભાવના રાખવી જરૂરી છે, એમ હું માનું છું. અને આપે આ સત્યને સાચી રીતે સાબિત કર્યું છે. શિક્ષણ અને કુશળતા વિકાસની જરૂરિયાતવાળા બાળકો, મહિલાઓ અને કિશોરો સુધી પહોંચી એમના માટે નફાકારક સંસ્થાઓની સ્થાપના કરવી, ભારતીય સેવામાં સખત, નવીન અને કલ્યાણકારી પોલીસની પહેલ કરવી , ખરેખર આ દરેક કાર્યો મને આપની પ્રશંસા કરવા મજબૂર કરે છે. જ્યારે જીવન ખૂબ સંઘર્ષ ભર્યું, કઠિન અને કંઈક શીખવી જાય એવું હોઇ, ત્યારે એ જીવન ઘણી સમજ આપી શકે છે. જો માણસ લેખક હોઈ, તો ઘણા લેખ પણ લખી શકે છે. કંઇક આવું જ હતું કે? આપની ઘણી બધી પુસ્તકો વિશે જાણ્યું છે, અને એ પુસ્તકો પૈકી, ‘What went wrong and why?’, ‘As i see’, ‘ हिम्मत है।’ આ તમામ પુસ્તકો વિશે મેં જાણ્યું છે અને ખરેખર એ જીવનોપયોગી હોઈ એમ હું અનુભવ કરું છું. અને આપના જીવનભરના અનુભવો કેવા કઠણ અને સંઘર્ષદાયી રહ્યા હશે એ અનુભવી શકું છું. એક લેખક તરીકે ,એક પોલીસ તરીકે આપ ખરેખર મારા આદર્શ રહ્યા છો. એક માર્ગદર્શક જ કહી શકાય. હું આપથી ખરેખર પ્રભાવિત છું. ઘણી બધી એવી વાતો આપ દ્વારા કહેવાયી છે જેનાથી હું પ્રભાવિત થઈ છું. શિક્ષણ અંગે, સંઘર્ષો બાબતથી, મનુષ્યના જીવન અંગે પણ આપે પોતાની સમજ રજૂ કરી છે. અને શિક્ષણ અંગેની આપની વિચારસરણીથી ખરેખર એક શીખ મળી કે, જો હું શિક્ષિત છું, સાચા ખોટાની સમજ રાખી શકું છું. અને મારી સામે કોઈક સાથે અન્યાય થઇ રહ્યો હોય, કંઈક ખોટું થઇ રહયું હોય, તેવા સમયે હું એનો વિરોધ ન કરું અથવા ચૂપ રહું, તો મારા શિક્ષણનું કોઈ જ મહત્વ ના ગણાય. અને જો સત્ય તમારી સાથે હોય, તો ભયને બાજુ પર રાખી નિર્ભયતાને અગ્ર સ્થાન આપવું યોગ્ય છે, એમ હું માનું છું.

આદરણીય કિરણ બેદી,તમે એક સ્ત્રી, એક પોલીસ ઑફિસર, એક લેખક તથા એક સામાજિક કાર્યકર્તા તરીકે મારા મનમાં એક જ્ઞાનસમજની મૂર્તિ બની રહ્યા છો. અને તેથી જ આપને મારા આદર્શ માનું છું.

લિ.
આપની આજ્ઞાકારી

Sakshi Patel

IT 3th SEM

excerpt.rendered: શ્રીમતિ કિરણ બેદી,સમાજ માં કેવા વ્યવહાર ને આદર્શ ગણવું? આ પરિભાષા ને જેને સાકરિત કરી, અને બાળપણથી જ જેઓ મારા આદર્શ રહ્યા છે, એવા શ્રીમતિ કિરણ બેદી આપને સંબોધવા હું આજે પ્રેરાઈ છું.કદાચ એ સાહસ, એ જુસ્સો મારામાં ન પણ હોઈ કે હું આપ જેવું મહાન કાર્ય કરી શકું, પણ હા તમારા જીવનને અનુલક્ષીને હું […]

content.rendered:
Dear Kishore da,

As far as I can remember, I have woken up from my afternoon naps with Bollywood classic songs playing on our television. This raw and perpetual exposure at a young age was one of the perks of being the daughter of a music fanatic. Every void in the day was filled with music, be it the upbeat remixes, melancholy blues or melodious romantics. Growing up in such a place makes one feel connected to music and singers in ways nothing else does. And I was lucky enough to feel this connection with you Kishore da. I have to thank you for the plethora of genres you wrote and sang for that now each of my moods has a great song to fall back on. It isn’t just your beautiful voice that has captured my heart but also the meaningful lyrics in most of them. All your songs take us through a journey and show us vivid images in a short span of 5 minutes. The benchmark you have set in playback singing hasn’t even be touched by anyone since you left us. It was because of your songs like khaike paan banaras wala, aanewala pal and pyaar diwana hota hai that made me watch their movies and introduced the world of classics to me. Of course, not all the movies you sang for were as entertaining. I can name a ton of movies with brilliant songs but crap plots.

During one of my binge-watching sessions, I came across Padosan, and I was pleasantly surprised to see my favorite singer playing a role in it. It was amusing to watch a pan chewing ustad going to great lengths so that his friend could woo the girl in samne wali khidki. I remember rolling on the floor, laughing to my hearts’ content during the sing-off in song ek chatur naar karke sringar. This was the moment I started seeing you in a new light. I had assumed that playback singers and lyricist had an air of seriousness around them and wouldn’t like being a laughing-stock. But here you were playing the role of a comedian with ease. When I discussed this with my parents, they simply laughed and showed me a list of movies where you played a comic role. Apparently, you were well-known for your comedy movies. This was the moment when your mechanic’s role in ek ladki bheegi bhagi si made sense to me. 

As if this new-found knowledge wasn’t enough that you surprised me again with your quirky habits. I was casually watching a news channel one day when a short 20 minutes long tribute for you came up. It said a bit about your eccentric behaviors. If I am not wrong didn’t you have a ‘Beware of Kishore’ sign outside your Warden road flat? One of the many questions I wanted to ask you was, why were you so paranoid about being paid. I mean going to the extent of shaving just a side of your face before a scene since you were only paid half the promised amount is unheard-of. People say that as you grew older your dislike towards everyone in general increased. I find that extremely hard to believe. How can someone who appears so friendly on-screen and who has sung so many jovial songs be a loner? Was this the reason behind marrying 4 times? Only you can answer thisquestion Kishore da.

Your ability to yodel perfectly, diverting to a nonsense rhyme and coming back to the original tune is exhilarating. And I hope it makes you happy to know that even now your songs are just as appreciated and your fan base has increased manifolds. There have been many singers who have tried copying your style and made remixes of your songs. But none of them have been able to deliver what you could. I always thought that one requires to be professionally trained in singing to become a playback singer but you broke the stereotype. Personally, I love those songs in which you collaborated with Rajesh Khanna, Lata Mangeshkar, and the Burmans. Your sudden death took everyone by surprise and left an ever-existing void in the music industry. But I hope that you are in a place jahan gham bhi na hoo aansun bhi na ho bas pyar hi pyar pale.

Yours sincerely,

Ek ajnabee haseen

Divyashree Iyer

IT 5th Sem

This raw and perpetual exposure at a young age was one of the perks of being the daughter of a music fanatic. Every void in the day was filled […]

content.rendered:
Dear Ranveer Allahabadia AKA Beerbiceps, co-founder of monk-entertainment and the creator of India’s top podcast channel TRS (The Ranveer show) with over 2 million subscribers on both YouTube channels. I was in 9th grade when I came across a YouTube channel owned by an engineering student and a fitness coach who was working hard to become a successful entrepreneur. I am grateful to have known you this early.

Just like you and millions out there, Dragonball Z is my favourite anime. You said in one of your podcasts that Dragon ball Z depicts that life is all about breaking the existing limits and evolving throughout our lives in all aspects like speed, strength and intellect. It is a great lesson for us, who want to strive greatness no matter what comes up in our way of success. Life is all about breaking the limits and evolving into a smarter, stronger and a better person.

I connect with you, cause just like you even I went through the dark days of IIT coaching for a year. Solving dozens of questions, completing assignments, weekly test and the unceasing feeling you get that there are lakhs of students out there, who are better than you haunts one down. But the whole experience gave me a lot of lessons that will always remain in my life. I didn’t crack IIT but the competitive atmosphere got me into thinking that if in life I will not work hard then there are millions out there who are dreaming the same dream which I am dreaming. So, if you want to achieve what you dream, you need to work harder, smarter, faster each day till you get what you want. Determination is everything.

In one of your podcasts (TRS-E8), you said, “My teacher always used to look down on me.”. I think being a backbencher in my school and college I can say that they look down on average, below-average students a lot. They are very fearful of the change, sometimes they say things which can shatter a student’s heart.
“IF YOU DONT GET A GOOD JOB, YOUR CAREER IS OVER!”.
My math teacher told me 2 weeks before my board exam that she doesn’t think that I can pass my board exams. Hearing this type of declarations by your teacher just two weeks before the paper can terribly affect your mindset, confidence and most importantly the belief you have in yourself. Some teachers even told me how scoring in school decides a lot about your future. They have gone through this phase and they have followed the traditional method of going to school, having a degree, ending with a job and go on paying the bills.
At that tender age when we don’t know much about life, we tend to believe that our percentage decides our fate. But it’s not like that, we are living in an era where there is an abundance of opportunity. What we really need is a desire to do something backed with insatiable faith in our desire. No one can stop you after that. Literally no one.

I learnt one thing very early that no matter how great you are doing there will always be someone who will try to pull you down. You must focus your mind on the positive aspects of life rather than worrying on negative comments but at the same time, we should try to learn from our mistakes. You are the only sensible influencer who can talk about anxiety, depression low self-esteem with so much clarity. The way you are trying to spread the knowledge about all this is simply commendable.

Your take on Yoga and meditation is like a modern-day saint. I was also very sceptic about all this but your videos have changed my perspective completely. Meditation is literally the art of doing nothing at all. Sitting comfortably for 10 minutes alone can solve most of your problems. We are so busy in our routine that sometimes we tend to suppress our negative thoughts instead of thinking about it. Letting your negative thoughts go is the first step towards self-control. Your mind is that weapon which can either destroy your problems or it can create your problems. The choice is yours. The essential point of understanding the mind is that liberation from suffering cannot be found outside the mind. Your mind has the questions of life and the answers of life both. You just need to find them!

You are an apostle of positivity. Your videos, podcasts and your actions are inspiring a lot of young kids. Keep sharing, inspiring and fueling the youth with positive energy!

From,
A small boy with many dreams.

Pruthvirajsinh Gohil

Mech. 3rd Sem

title.rendered: An open letter to M.S. Dhoni

content.rendered:
Hello Mr Captain Cool,

I grew up seeing your tenacious and finesse cricket as a wicketkeeper-batsman from my cricketing days at school. A lot has to be said but a mighty congratulation to you for being honoured with the prestigious Padma Bhushan award. It’s just “Thank you Dhoni!”. For a man of your prestige, words shall never legitimatize who you are. Your arrival always gives “cricketing- INDIA” hope. It always is awe-inspiring for me to see you in the field. Your ‘work hard-stay dedicated’ approach towards life encourages me towards the best in me. This simplicity of yours makes you a person of unique stature. Belonging to a small town; doing the job of a ticket checker, crushing between the platforms and struggling for the achievement of your goal inspire many young cricketers from small and big cities. I was carried away on the same bandwagon who believed that you were born under the lucky star and good luck drove your success. I am sorry I was wrong. As Vince Lombardi said “Winners never quit and quitters never win”, you’re a set example of the same to me. It has always been one more time and one more opportunity. During setbacks and under-performance; retrospection, observation and calmness were the keys I learnt from you. Your selfless attitude, passion, team spirit, sportsmanship, dedication and the list keep getting longer with more and more values you inculcate; you are a perfect role model for me and many others. You can keep the crowd waiting with bated breath by taking the match to its end and then winning it by hitting a massive beyond the ropes!

Criticism never outraged you. Everyone has haters. But they end up as your fans. Up to this day, I muse on how you manage to stay calm and cool (which you once lost over a teammate); be it on the field as a player or as a spokesperson for the Indian cricket team. I do become sceptical when you bat down the order whereas batting up the order is your forte. The Day: 11/7/2019 (NZ vs IND), social media was flooded with: “That at 5 for 3, 1.25 billion people still believed.” The belief: Dhoni was still to bat and pull the winning shot. But so near yet so far! I had teary eyes. Shattered; by seeing the dismay, you walked to stands and yours not so in-form gameplay. But we, the MSD fans love and idolise you more than ever. Although you’re a sportsman, you are a pro cryptic communicator. It always baffles the opposition team, no matter how hard they try. They never succeed in deciphering especially when you’re behind the stumps. I still dream to master it. Finding an end to your achievements seems to be a wild goose chase. Yes, they’re never-ending. People enjoy your company.” Mahi” is the name by which we all adore you. I wish to rejoice your company of humour, sarcasm viz: – the Australian reporter who questioned your retirement and determination. The way you amuse your daughter Ziva and joke around with the junior teammates, makes me burst out with laughter. Perhaps you are a complete social package off the field.

A grand salute to you for being ranked as the Lieutenant Colonel on November 1, 2011. I would like to hear about this big day whenever I get a chance to meet you. I want to tell you about a common interest we share, it’s the love for bikes. Well, I have the craziness for cars too. Though I could not have them all, posters on the wall and pictures in my gallery exhilarate me. A special request, please give me a visit of your grand collection bike garage.

Down the memory lane, it was the grand day itself when cheeks turned pink and tears of joy, happiness and triumph rolled down from eyes of over 115 crore countrymen just because of your leadership and team efforts; the World Cup was won by India after 28 years. Your unbeaten records till date as a captain and as a player add glory to the Indian cricket. Keep shining with crowning glory because there’s a lot more cricket left in you. The captain was just a title with responsibility, but I feel blessed to have a torchbearer like you leading. Here it comes: “M.S. Dhoni finishes off in style!”.

Yours Sincerely,

An enthusiastic henchman

Vrajal Chokshi

IT 7th Sem

excerpt.rendered: Hello Mr Captain Cool, I grew up seeing your tenacious and finesse cricket as a wicketkeeper-batsman from my cricketing days at school. A lot has to be said but a mighty congratulation to you for being honoured with the prestigious Padma Bhushan award. It’s just “Thank you Dhoni!”. For a man of your prestige, words […]

title.rendered: An Open Letter To Bill Gates

content.rendered:
Dear Mr. Bill Gates,

Could we be friends? I would be flattered to be a friend of such a kind, brilliant, rich, techno-savvy, gentleman, like you. Sharing the same interests, I dream to become like you one day in my life. It might amuse you at first why I choose you to be friends with. Well, your combative nature, intelligence, and competence made me choose you. To my new friend, I would like to say that your diligence, marketing, and business tactics inspire me to take the path, you once rolled on. Marking your footsteps has got me to a new level in my student life. I might not be as competent as you to drop my studies and set out my own venture, but I surely have ideas booming up. Seeing you on the television, social media and in the books is an awe-inspiring feeling altogether. I first heard your name from my computer teacher in 2nd grade and attached to it, was the word “billionaire’. In those days you were my favorite because you were rich. In the process of gaining maturity, I got to know a lot more about you. The word “billionaire” with your name was now replaced by a new magical word “Microsoft”. And, this had brought all the difference in computing. It was later than sooner to have known by me that you made that blue screen appear every time I switched on the computer in my school lab. You might hate me for hating that blue screen, but I was so young then.

Dear Mr. Gates, the computing or perhaps the whole world appreciates your product as well as you. Microsoft and the Windows software developed by you and your friend Paul Allen has made life at home and office really productive, manageable and easy. Microsoft software solutions took the world by storm. Microsoft Office is that salient feature which has made making projects, managing databases and giving presentations an easy task. Your acumen for software development and rolling out Microsoft Windows raised the bar for other software and graphics imagery companies. Considering your aggressive business tactics, you have pioneered them very well. Being in the Forbes’ annual list of the top 400 wealthiest people in America in your 20s sounds very motivating to me every time I go through your achievements. A fact that upset me for a while was that you along with Microsoft had been sued multiple times for bad business practices. Did you really practice them or was it a marketing strategy that was interpreted wrongly? Clarification is still awaited. Leaving the flaws behind and working your way towards success, productivity and freedom expelled a creative approach of yours to me. Being rich has its own perks, but being kind is what the whole world learns from you. Dear pal, I wish you keep up the Samaritan work. The world needs it.

Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation for the underprivileged is doing a wonderful job on your behalf. Looking at your works of charity and philanthropy I wish to share one of my life-changing experience. I participated in an event in my school days for donating clothes and food items to the needy ones. It really was an amazing and heart-warming experience. It surely brought smiles to many. Keep spreading the message of harmony and peace through education and charity along with Mrs. Gates, for the betterment of society. You once quoted “Television is not real life. In real life, people actually have to leave the coffee shop and go to jobs” makes me feel amused. I can’t figure out how clear you convey the message of hard work by jumbling up these simple words. Well, being quite funny at times and strict at work is really a good regime. All in all, I would say that keep motivating me because I wish to become like you one day.

Your New Friend?

Vrajal Chokshi

IT 6th sem

Sharing the same interests, I dream to become like you one day in my life. It might amuse you at first why I choose you to be friends with. […]

content.rendered:
Open letter
To Bollywood,
I must have been in 6th standard when Sab TV had started to telecast romantic dramas of the 60s and 70s. I must have seen its promotional advertisement while watching one of those daily soaps which have a tendency to stretch every minute thing. I must have been at my leisure or my mom must have been so busy since she wasn’t bugging me to study, that I decided to invest my Sunday afternoon on Kati Patang. That was best decision that I had ever taken in my life. Subsequent three hours were filled with ever so handsome Rajesh Khanna silently falling in love with his best friend’s widow with the back drop of luscious green hills. With the addition of amazing music scores, I soon lost my heart to this perennial film.
It wasn’t long before I started looking forward to my mother’s grocery visits so that I could get my hands on as many movies as possible. It has been more than 100 years since the first-ever Indian film directed by Dadasaheb Phalke came out. He must have had no clue as to how humongous this industry might get. Today, thousands of youngsters from all around the country come to Mumbai each year to try their luck in Bollywood. Unlike your production houses, I might not be able to pinpoint the true reason behind this madness but I can assume it must be because in the past century you have launched films that call out of people from all fields of life. It doesn’t matter how strange one’s preferences are, one is sure to find a Hindi movie that completes them.
From the plethora of genres we have, the crowd-pleaser has to be Romance. It is quite a task to find a movie without a love story these days due to the exceptional talent possessed by Filmmakers for adding a love angle in the darkest of movies. But I am sure that it hasn’t always been like that. Wasn’t it considered a taboo to show romance on a big screen in those days? It must have been a bold move in the 1930s that the first romantic film- Devdas was released. Thankfully, there has been no turning back since then.
As the years went by, the number of romantic Bollywood movies releasing doubled up. Day by day the fan base for light-hearted comedies like Amol Palekar’s Gol Maal increased while classics like Mughal-E-Azam left audiences teary-eyed. When our society was filled with prejudice and scepticism we were shown a world in which romance blossoms between an indigent writer and a prostitute in Pyaasa. Movies like Rajnigandha showed the fragility of a relationship through the perspective of a woman whose roving thoughts and fickle mind makes her see limitations in her would be partner when an erstwhile lover comes back in her life. It was the first movie that showed me life wasn’t a fairy tale and finding your true love is indeed difficult when more than one prince charming are knocking your door. Just as progressive some movies were, others were equally shallow. Even though movies like Chandani and DDLJ have been famous nationwide and have made a fortune in box office they have heavily promoted gender stereotyping. We have loved watching Shahrukh Khan tease Kajol and the extend till which Rishi Kapoor went to woo Sridevi. But is that justifiable? Such movies have time and again fooled with young lover’s hearts and made boys believe that “ladki ki na mei hi uski haan hoti hai”, while girls are asked to assume that if a boy is being mean then he is probably in love with you.
Your filmmakers are breaking norms and social taboos since ages by stunning us with diverse content but still, it is awful hard to find LGBTQ inclusive content. But calling you out over here is wrong since us viewers haven’t supported movies like Fire and Aligarh which leaves us spellbound with its fantastic portrayal of same-sex relations, infidelity and honour killing. Now, since we are on the topic of infidelity I must say that Bollywood hasn’t left many stones unturned on this subject. We have seen how life-shattering and esteem crumbling it can be through a secret affair between the protagonist in Silsila and Kabhi Alvida Na Kehna. Movies like Lunchbox have kept me awake till wee hours of the morning since I wasn’t able to comprehend if cheating is alright if you are in an unhappy relationship.
You have provided a warm blanket to cosy me up after I burned the midnight oil and also given me a reality check when I missed one too many boats. Even though you have been setting unrealistic standards for lovers across India since my grandmother was a little girl, I will never stop adoring you.

Divyashree Iyer

IT, 4th Sem.

I must have seen its promotional advertisement while watching one of those daily soaps which have a tendency to stretch every minute thing. I must have been at my leisure or my […]

title.rendered: AN OPEN LETTER TO AUGUSTUS WATERS AND HAZEL GRACE

content.rendered:
Dear Augustus Waters and Hazel Grace,

           ‘Happily ever after’ was a thing I watched growing up. I believed that true love always finds a way for two persons to be together and spend their lives happily. Cheesiness was something I could never remove from the concept of romance. Then, you guys came along and changed it all.

         From Augustus introducing his metaphor regarding the cigarettes to Hazel’s idea of infinity world, you guys gave me a forever. Augustus, you taught us an important lesson in friendship by being there for Issac when he broke up with his girlfriend and sharing your last dying wish with Hazel. Like a lot of us, you wanted to do something great and be remembered forever and the greatest regret when you were on the verge of your death was that it couldn’t happen in your case in spite of you being a capable person. Yet when Hazel explained how being remembered by our loved ones meant more than anything you understood it. We all learned that lesson along with you.

           Hazel Grace Lancaster, you are a true fighter. Oblivion is inevitable and I believe the same. Rather I should say you made me believe so. You confessed your love for Augustus in the most beautiful way and lived your little infinity with him in a way everyone craves for. When you said that being a sick child doesn’t make you that sad but being a sick child for your parents made you felt bad, that made a huge impact on me.

I have seen people in my life who have successfully battled cancer and by looking at them I feel that we are lucky to have life in our hands. I feel proud of them because they have fought the illness which so many people have fallen prey to. They inspire me to fight whatever situation comes in my life. Unfortunately, surviving it is not possible in all cases. Keeping love ignited when you know that you might die any day is what makes you live a long life even in less time.

When Augustus died, it broke my heart too along with Hazel’s. But you know what Augustus? It was a privilege to have my heart broken by you. Thank you for breaking my heart so beautifully. I never thought it was ever possible for me to appreciate a sad ending and also at the same time to fall in love with it. I have now understood that the universe is not a wish-granting factory, but sometimes, wishes do come true. The universe grants in the most  amazing ways at the most unexpected moments. One should appreciate the smallest simplest pleasures of their life and be thankful for it.

Your story filled in me this weird evangelical zeal and made me convinced that the shattered world will never be put together until and unless we appreciate the relevance of small joys in our life. Pain always demands to be felt! You guys made an impression on millions of people. People just like you, some not, and those of us who are somewhere in between.

            Thanks for making people like me believe in smaller infinities.

Okay? Okay

From,

A believer in smaller infinities.

Sruthi Chervullil

EC, 4th Sem

I believed that true love always finds a way for two persons to be together and spend their lives happily. Cheesiness was something I could never remove from the concept of romance. Then, you guys came along and […]

title.rendered: AN OPEN LETTER TO AMISH TRIPATHI

content.rendered:
Dear Amish,

           I don’t consider myself a frequent reader and books relating to mythology have never been of huge interest to me. Hence, it was not surprising to any of my friends when I responded with cynicism when they recommended your Shiva Trilogy over and over again. One of them finally thrust a copy of Immortals of Meluha at me and forced me to read it.

           Stuck on a rail journey of almost 36 hours, I had nothing to do. So I started reading the Immortals of Meluha. You have written the story in a well-paced manner and that kept me engrossed. The way you have described Shiva, the marijuana smoking Tibetian immigrant, who cannot adapt to the stoic ways of the Meluhans yet who is open with his hugs without inhibition is simply magical. You make your readers learn to like him, want him to win, to celebrate with him and cry with him. Your fan-boyish love and admiration towards Shiva is clearly observed in every line of the tale. Now I like Shiva as a man of flesh and blood rather than a diety.

           When I read the book what amazed me was that you have given equal priority to all the portrayal of the female characters. There are female warriors, the prime minister of the nation is itself a strong woman and of course the heroine of the tale, Sati has been shown as a woman who has enough backbone to fight an army of enemies. Even Shiva’s attraction towards Sati is on the grounds of her courage rather than the beauty or other stereotypically feminine attributes. Your way of thinking about equality of sexes for social growth and progress is admirable. A society built purely based on merit and not on caste, race or gender; this utopian ideal is examined with brutal honesty in your every book.

           I knew that Sati would die from the starting even then when I read the way you described it, it nearly brought me in tears. Many avid fans of yours who followed the three books from the beginning were quite disappointed by the understated climax. However, I loved it because I guess you avoided the usually opted cliché route. As a Shiva fan, which you make every normal person who reads the book; one expects the cliché turnabout that Shiva will choose the righteous path that he as Neelkanth is espoused to. 

Not you, though. 

You have portrayed Shiva as human as possible from the starting of the book. One with human failings and emotional upheavals. Shiva is not a god and you proved it that even great men can lose kindness and compassion in the face of enormous loss. 

           After completing the Trilogy, I read the Scion of Ishvaku. It was awesome to go through the world that you created. Now I’m eagerly waiting for your next publication. You transformed me from a person with zero interest in mythology to a person who doesn’t miss a mythological book.

Har Har Mahadev!

 

Sruthi Cheruvullil

EC 4th Sem

Hence, it was not surprising to any of my friends when I responded with cynicism when they recommended your Shiva Trilogy over and over again. One of them […]

title.rendered: An Open Letter to Robin Sharma

content.rendered:
Respected Robin Sharma,

It is a moment of greatness writing down this letter to you. I am a dedicated follower and an admirer of your thoughts and teachings, who have benefitted from the various masterclasses you conduct. Being a premier thinker on leadership, personal growth and life management you carry a huge responsibility of making life worth living, the easy way.  As the saying goes, “Even the darkest cloud has a silver lining” your wisdom of words gave me that vision to fight against the toughest of the situations while progressing in life. “Megaliving” is the book that made me reconceptualize every aspect of life when it was topsy-turvy. The subtle touches of Indian philosophies and yoga in your texts kept me going with this book of yours, probably the first in this segment. It was an interesting read altogether. As a lawyer, you are very contemplative, which takes you to the depth of each and every aspect of a successful life and it reflects in your work ultimately.

Robin sir, you are a pool of humbleness and positivity, I’m really baffled to which quality of yours shall I inculcate first. Motivation and self-help segment was not my cup of tea until I was gifted with your bestselling titles” The Monk Who Sold His Ferrari” by my uncle. Till today it holds the prestige of being one of my favorite reads. When it comes to your genre of writing, many of my mates criticized some piece of your works, for having very long procedures in attaining a quality, which hits them with boredom. I wish if you could inculcate some simple stories for conveying your thought, because as a reader that would deepen the interest in reading the book. In this fastmoving world, nobody has the time to read a book and have the patience to follow the 30 days procedure. Frankly, I won’t be able to do it myself. We can’t change so easily. Our mind is set in a way to react, to what we feel is right. Hope you consider this tiny suggestion. There is surely more to learn from you, then to accept failure and loose at life. Mr. Sharma, you always show appreciation for your parents and family, who support you and give your wisdom of thought a new edge. The following lines from -The Mastery Manual: “Remember there are no real-life failures in life only results. There are no true tragedies, only lessons. And there are no problems only opportunities for growth waiting to be recognized as a solution by the person of wisdom”, shall remain eternal. It’s not me who’s appreciating you and your works, but the people from lowest designation in an office to CEOs of big corporate houses are present in that successful fraternity. More of an author then a lawyer your Style is interactive, not didactic. You know how some people are, who inspire from their own energy and lifestyle. You do that.

Sir, the more I learn from you, the more positive and productive I become at life. After all, life is all about taking birth, fulfilling your task and saying good-bye, you add something more in between the latter two phases making it a meaningful and an exciting one. You have helped a lot through your words in raising the bar and unleashing the true potential within me. As you quoted in your book- “The Mastery Manual”, “The tragedy of life is not death but what we let die inside of us while we live”, makes all the difference of rising up once again and achieving our goal. I admire you and your works, and I’m very grateful for all the change that has happened.

Yours sincerely,

Vrajal Chokshi


Vrajal Chokshi

IT, 5th Sem

I am a dedicated follower and an admirer of your thoughts and teachings, who have benefitted from the various masterclasses you conduct. Being a premier thinker on leadership, personal growth and life management you carry a huge responsibility of making […]

title.rendered: AN OPEN LETTER TO DAN BROWN

content.rendered:
Dear Dan Brown, 

I knew not what an amazing world is withheld in books until I came across one of yours. Today, I know a myriad of mind-numbing facts about the world and humanity that I wouldn’t have known otherwise and I have only your brilliance to thank. I, who has never travelled to more than the next city, has been on thrilling adventures across the globe, and yet, I have only you to thank. The person who would never even consider reading a book is now an avid reader. In a way, you’ve helped me open my eyes to see this planet more clearly than ever before.  

I was made aware of your genius existence through Inferno. I remember questioning the thrill factor of a book that thick when I first saw the monstrous copy lying in my sister’s bag. Back then, my interest in a book was inversely proportional to its size. When I first picked up the book, I thought of it as a big boring brick. But the reviews on the jacket had me questioning my judgment. I decided to give it a shot and try something new. Three days later, I lay still with the book in my lap – dumbstruck, completely awed and embarrassed by my former shortsightedness.  

After being completely possessed by Inferno, I craved to read more of the same. You have a certain gift to engage the readers. I live for the thrill of the chase. I often find myself in a realm of madness. You construct a horizon where fiction and reality merge to an extent that it’s hard to believe that it is in fact, fiction. I take my hat off to the excruciating amount of research that would’ve been done behind just one book. The way in which all that research is incorporated in the book is exceptional. The purpose of entire organizations put in a nutshell, renowned historical artefacts placed in a new light, vivid word paintings of beautiful cities and museums across the world, ancient symbols, traditions, religions and, societies. All that packed within a chain of shocking events and conspiracies that’ll leave the reader astonished. Truly there’s so much to take away from a Dan Brown book. 

You are known for raising questions on societal norms and cultural traditions. A careful and brave exploration into the truth and history of humankind is bound to push some panic buttons and raise controversy, especially when you state explicitly that all facts are real. Whilst I feel that the way you challenge beliefs is one-sided, I can’t help but admire your bravado. In an interview, you said that you are on a spiritual journey towards exploring “the truth” that began when you were thirteen. You started exploring the contradictions between religion and science. The way you bravely put your truth out there has garnered my respect apart from worldwide criticism. Your way of expressing thoughts through the protagonist encourages discussion; it compels the reader to consider it instead of outright rejecting it. Without a doubt, your work in its genre is outstanding. 

However, with the number of ‘Dan Browns’ I’ve read, the plot became painfully predictable. It doesn’t take much time to derive the special Dan Brown formula which you’ve used in all your books. The brilliant plot twists that once had my stomach in knots, make me laugh and scorn at their predictability now. This ‘formula’ of yours, is a deal-breaker for most people. But even though said formula is quite disappointing, it does little to affect how I feel about your books. Despite the existence of the formula, I need them to step out of my routine life, to be awed and to be entertained. 

“Good boys don’t ask questions like that.”- if the priest told you something else when you questioned the contradictions, maybe your beliefs would have been different. I want to join you on your journey. Like yourself and many others, I have an innate desire to explore the history of our existence, and to consume all the knowledge about the world that there is. To seek answers to questions that can’t just be googled. But I’ve been too lazy to do so. Finding about you was like a waking call. You served as a catalyst in my quest. You’ve made me more than just a reader. I will forever be gratuitous for that. 

Yours respectfully, 

A truly thankful soul.

Today, I know a myriad of mind-numbing facts about the world and humanity that I wouldn’t have known otherwise and I have only your brilliance to thank. I, who has never travelled to more […]

title.rendered: AN OPEN LETTER TO CHESTER BENNIGTON

content.rendered:
Dear Chester,

I was merely 10 when I heard your first song, it was probably my first English song and I was hooked. I don’t know why I kept going back to this song and listening to it time and time again, I didn’t understand anything about it but I don’t know why whenever the lines “ In the end, it doesn’t even matter” came up I had to sing it. I still remember me and my 10 year old friends singing along these lines in chorus, trying to act all cool as if it became our life’s anthem. I think for that entire year I knew just one song and this song will stay with me forever. Your song opened my eyes to this entire new world of Rock music and I can never thank you enough for this. Linkin Park was just my go to band for every situation, I was never the person who could express myself but your songs made me realize that there’s always someone I can relate with.

Your music has stayed with me in every phase of my life and  it’s as if when know one taught me to live ,you were there to show me that I was not alone and I could do a lot better. There were times when I thought whatever I was doing was not worthwhile and “Somewhere I belong” gave me that push in the back and told me it was alright and it was going to be okay and somehow in the end it always did get better. Whenever I sought companionship and things did not go my way, “Crawling” and “Lost in the echo” were the songs I would always go back to and I still do, I survived the harsh parts of it as these songs played in my head.

From the moment I did not even know about what any song meant to the point when I admired you and your ability to understand me, singing on my behalf and for me, I forgot there was a Chester Bennington apart from Linkin Park who’s was so hurt that he had to start thinking that there’s nobody to save him.

Chester I am sorry I could never understand the pain and sorrow behind those lyrics, I am sorry that the pain you felt inside was too great for you to live with anymore and I am sorry that you felt like nobody was here who could help you even a little bit. Almost 2 years ago when I heard what happened I was just distraught, it felt as if someone very close to my heart had left , I couldn’t imagine a world where I won’t be listening to new Linking Park songs anymore. Instead, to deal with my grief, I want to thank you for the music that you have made

I am someone who listens to whatever feels nice to my ears, I have had so many phases with music but each phase became a part of me if not a constant. And your rebellious attitude and ability to read my mind makes you stand out among the others, Chester. You’ll be greatly missed and the world will miss your ability to read minds and express them as your thoughts. However, I have your songs to turn to for solace or whenever I want to escape from this world for a few minutes.

As I sit here and stare at this poster of you on my wall while listening to “Shadow of the day”, I want to thank you for everything you have done, for your contribution to this world, for giving me strength and for being you. I am sorry the pain and struggles and I wish I could have done something to make your feel just little bit better. Now that you are completely free, unshackled from the struggles, I want you to know that the shadow off the day will embrace the world in grey and sun will set for you.

From,
Someone who cares about that ‘One light’ in a sky of a million stars.

excerpt.rendered: Dear Chester, I was merely 10 when I heard your first song, it was probably my first English song and I was hooked. I don’t know why I kept going back to this song and listening to it time and time again, I didn’t understand anything about it but I don’t know why whenever the […]

title.rendered: AN OPEN LETTER TO SIR STEPHEN HAWKING

content.rendered:
Dear Sir,

For years I have wondered that although there are millions of scientists and researchers spending their entire lives in the science laboratories and research centres trying to unravel the mystery of the Universe; how could a theoretical physicist, who couldn’t convey his words through his own voice, is able to associate the entire world to think upon the idea of origin of our Universe. You are an inspiration for an entire generation of space lovers and especially for the young brains of 21st century, who have acquired ample information of black holes and its peculiar characteristics from your books. You always came up with startling revelations and theories on which the entire world would debate for days.

It is quite interesting to turn up the pages of recent history to study your life as a whole. You belonged to a family, which was highly respected by the society for the intelligence. It is said that your family spent time reading books while having meals. Although your father wished that you could clear the scholarship test and get an admission to Westminster School, due your illness and poor financial situation of the family you had to continue with your schooling at St. Albania School. I was amazed to know that at the age of eight, you had created a computer using the parts of clock and other recyclable things. Definitely your classmates had given you the right nickname- ‘Einstein’. Although Mathematics was your first love, you pursued Physics at University College. You were the first person to work at the Department of Mathematics and Theoretical Physics at the University of Cambridge. Your theory of ‘Properties of Expansion of Universe’ gained you a doctorate in the field of cosmology. Relating to Einstein’s theory of relativity, you tried to define the journey of this Universe, which began from a Big Bang and is considered to end in a black hole. The discovery of Hawking radiation was one of the remarkable works of your life.

At the age of 21, when you were diagnosed with ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis), a motor neuron disease, you decided to fight back. The constant support of your wife Jane gave you the inner strength to fight through the tough phase of your life. Where the doctor had predicted your life to be for a couple of years, you fought bravely with it for last fifty-five years. In one of your interviews I have read that the disease had made you a lazy student of Cambridge a renowned scientist of the world. When the disease started affecting your life, you were bound to give up your teaching career. However, you fought with the situation and came up with a wheelchair and a computer program that can speak for you. You are an inspiration for 4.5 million people who are suffering from the same disease. You have shown the world how to make friends with your own disabilities and move on in life.

In my opinion I feel that Science is not a field where you bet on your works. It stands unjustified to compare the research hours with money. However, I think these bets have invoked an urge in people to know about the Universe. Your predictions of Black Holes reverberated across the world when the NASA confirmed the existence of gravitational waves.

Like your theories, the news of your death was shocking revelation for this Universe. Although I know that you were an Atheist, I would say that the disabilities of your life were the evil plans of the Creator of this Universe to keep his existence a mystery.  

May Your Soul Rest in Peace.

excerpt.rendered: Dear Sir, For years I have wondered that although there are millions of scientists and researchers spending their entire lives in the science laboratories and research centres trying to unravel the mystery of the Universe; how could a theoretical physicist, who couldn’t convey his words through his own voice, is able to associate the entire […]

title.rendered: An Open Letter to Robert Downey Jr.

content.rendered:
Dearest Sir,

You’ve taken us on an odyssey, one where our struggles were almost as much as yours. Even after all that that followed, how did you turn out to be so perfect? Maybe your rollercoaster-like life with rising stardom to obscurity and then a phoenix-like rebirth is perhaps what resulted into perfect.

I’m not going to lie, I didn’t want to watch ‘Iron Man’ rather, I was hellbent on not watching it. Being an obsessive hardcore comic reader, I couldn’t contemplate the idea of someone playing a character from my favourite comics, let alone the prominent Tony Stark. It was when a friend of mine forced me to watch, did I do it and boy was I not blown away. I never imagined that a character of such calibre could be played so well and I’m glad that you proved me wrong. By the time the movie was over, you had us all pledged to the eternal nerdhood. A bit of crass and crude with a dash of humour, is what makes your movie so memorable and ‘Kiss Kiss Bang Bang’ was such, right? I never expected for a movie to be so violent yet be portrayed in a pop culture form. I loved your energy, charm and your slyly wry acting, and maybe that was what helped a cult-class movie find its rightful audience. I thought I had seen the best of your performances you had offered till then. You blew my such wrong assumptions of you to shreds when I stumbled upon your masterpiece ‘Chaplin’. By the time you convinced the producer that you indeed were the real Chaplin, you had us drooling over your acting too.

You became the living embodiment of Tony Stark, and I hate you for that. Yes, sir, even though you are the perfect Tony Stark that can ever be, I hate you or perhaps that is the reason as to why. You played the character so proficiently that no one can replace you. I know that there’ll come a time when you are not Tony Stark and I’m not just ready for that time. Maybe it’s selfish of me, but please, sir, don’t ever leave us.

Sir, you were a superhero even before Iron Man made you into one. You had hit rock bottom, you had been to jail for drug issues and to rehab, you lost everything you had, and even after that, when it seemed impossible to recover, not only did you come back but you took the world by storm. You taught us that it’s never too late and never too difficult to overcome the seemingly ghastly problems, once we decide to act on it. Sir, I admire you for your compassionate and loving and friendly nature. When a new actor joins the team, you go out of your way to make them feel welcomed. I love how you throw little dinner parties for some new cast member just so that they won’t feel left out. Mostly, I love how you don’t give a care about others at the time of helping someone, whether it may be a close friend of yours or a stranger you just saw. It is with examples like this that you teach us the true significance of small deeds filled with empathy, in someone’s life.

Lastly, sir, your life has been an inspiration and your bromance with Jude Law a to-die-for dream. You have made a special place in our hearts and it’ll be forever be yours. Even without a suit, sir, you are a genius, billionaire, playboy, philanthropist.

Yours Sincerely,
One of the countless fans

Utsav Parmar

CE, 4th Sem.

Maybe your rollercoaster-like life with rising stardom to obscurity and then a phoenix-like rebirth is perhaps what resulted into perfect. I’m not […]

title.rendered: AN OPEN LETTER TO EMPEROR Aśoka

content.rendered:
Appraisal to Aśoka the Great,

In my childhood, the story which attracted me the most was the Kalinga War- the War that gave birth to Devānaṃpiya Aśoka from the ashes of ChandAśoka (the Cruel Aśoka). The quest for you continued through the graveled roads of distorted history, through the maze of contradictory rock edicts and through the thick forests of history books. But you always hid yourself behind the curtains of time and history. Like a little boy, I sat down disappointed and was surprised to realise that ‘on the patriarchal shores of supremacy and dominance, I was assimilating the pebbles of an Emperor’s life, who had cherished a beautiful childhood playing in the ocean of motherhood’. I turned up my sails to excavate your history from her story- the biography of Devi Subhadrangi.

Your mother, Subhadrangi preached and lived a life of non-violence, simplicity, honesty and self-satisfaction, which impressed King Bindusaar and gave her the title of Dharma. However the palace politics had always kept you and your mother away from the soil of Patliputra. You were born to her at a time of utmost difficulty and had put a beautiful smile on her face, thus becoming her Aśoka (terminator of sorrow). How fiercely you had fought with a lion to save Acharya Chanakya! Bringing you and Queen Dharma to Magadh, Acharya Chanakya infused the seeds of AkhandBharatvarsh (an Integrated India) in you. It’s pragmatic to see that where our modern society stumbles to be tolerant to new ideologies, you uprooted the Varna System and propagated the ideologies of secularism and equality under the eyes of law.

In the game of power acquisition, you turned very cruel towards your opponents and your step-brothers, walking off from the path of righteousness. Protecting your pregnant wife, Devi from the evil plans of your step-brother Sushim, Queen Dharma welcomed the fate to take her life. Embracing the throne of Magadh, you began the journey-a journey of bloodshed to fulfil the dream of AkhandBharatvarsh . No one would deny that Kalinga War was the turning point of your life. Kalinga was the only feudal republic state, where the peasants, farmers and fishermen joined hands with the soldiers to fight for their motherland. In the history of mankind, it was the one such war that was charged against the civilians. Your patriotism for your motherland had blindfolded you to see the patriotism of your subjects. Slaughtering humanity on the banks of River Daya, you had annexed Kalinga. The dead and mutilated bodies on the war field had turned the river red and mourning cries of grieving widows and children completely had shook your inner conscience. Unlike great rulers like Raavan and Hitler, you were one of the fortunate rulers to have got a chance to repent for your deeds and devote rest of your life to ahimsa. The quality of acceptance and tolerance inspired me and taught me to walk on the path of Dhamma, which you had laid down. The birth of Devānaṃpiya Piyadasī Aśoka began an era of relative peace, harmony and prosperity.

It’s said that during cremation, your body burned for seven days. But the fire against discrimination, which you had ignited, would keep burning on Indian soil forever. The Lion Capital of Sarnath witnesses the modern India leading with the golden phrase: Satyamev Jayate. When the pigeons of peace and harmony would wave its wings, you would be commemorated in the hearts of each individual. As H.G. Wells had rightly said,

“Amidst the tens of thousands of names of monarchs that crowd the columns of history … the name of Aśoka shines, and shines almost alone, a star.”

Yours faithfully,
Nirmal Sunil

Nirmal Sunil

MH, 4th Sem.

The quest for you continued through the graveled roads of distorted history, through the maze of contradictory rock edicts and […]
